Title: Gustav Mahler - Symphony no. 1: Rafael Kubelik conducting the LSO in 1975
Description:
Rafael Kubelik conducting the London Symphony Orchestra at the Royal Festival Hall in Mahler's first symphony, to a tumultuous reception.

1. Langsam, schleppend 0:00
2. Kräftig bewegt, doch nicht zu schnell 15:30
3. Feierlich und gemessen, ohne zu schleppen 22:50
4. Stürmisch bewegt – Energisch 33:27

This channel is not associated in any way with the London Symphony Orchestra, or its own CD label, LSO LIVE. These are audio recordings made by LSO fans over a period of some 60 years, and are not rips of LSO LIVE recordings. We have greatly enjoyed these performances over the years and just wish to share them with other music lovers. No copyright infringement is intended; please make contact if there is an issue.

3. Moderato 07:38
4. Allegretto 12:41
5. Andante con moto 15:18

Title: Mahler: Symphony No. 5, Kubelík & COA (1951) マーラー 交響曲第5番 クーベリック
Description:
Gustav Mahler (1860-1911)
Symphony No. 5 in C-sharp minor

(00:05) 1. In gemessenem Schritt. Streng. Wie ein Kondukt.
(11:40) 2. Stürmisch bewegt. Mit grösster Vehemenz.
(24:49) 3. Kräftig, nicht zu schnell.
(40:52) 4. Adagietto. Sehr langsam.
(50:17) 5. Rondo-Finale. Allegro giocoso

Rafael Jeroným Kubelík (1914-1996), Conductor
Concertgebouw Orchestra Amsterdam (Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra)

Rec. 21 June 1951

グスタフ・マーラー
交響曲第5番 嬰ハ短調

(00:05) 1. 葬送行進曲 (正確な速さで。厳粛に。葬列のように)
(11:40) 2. 嵐のように荒々しく動きをもって。最大の激烈さを持って。
(24:49) 3. スケルツォ (力強く、速すぎずに)
(40:52) 4. アダージェット (非常に遅く)
(50:17) 5. ロンド - フィナーレ (快速に、楽しげに)

Description:

II. Poco adagio 11:30
III. Scherzo. Vivace 20:45
IV. Finale. Allegro 28:10 

BRITANNICA: Rafael Kubelík [was a] Bohemian-born Swiss conductor, musical director, and composer, who was noted for his frequent guest appearances with major orchestras throughout the world. He was a son of the violinist Jan Kubelík and studied composition and conducting at the Prague Conservatory. He conducted the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra from 1936 to 1939 and from 1942 to 1948. He left Czechoslovakia in 1948 after the Communist takeover, settling first in England and later in Switzerland, where he became a citizen in 1973. He became principal conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in 1950 but was forced to resign in 1953 amid controversy over his plans for staff changes and a concert program emphasizing modern compositions. As music director of the Covent Garden Opera from 1955 to 1958, he championed opera in English. From 1961 to 1979 he was principal conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra. From 1973 to 1974 he was also musical director of the Metropolitan Opera in New York City. Kubelík’s own compositions include two operas, three symphonies, choral works, and concertos.

BRITANNICA: Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra [is a] German symphony orchestra based in Munich and supported by the state of Bavaria. Under the aegis of the Bavarian state radio station, conductor Eugen Jochum organized the performing group in 1949, trained it to become a major orchestra, and took it to perform at the prestigious Edinburgh International Festival in 1957. Jochum continued to conduct the orchestra until 1960. In 1961 Raphael Kubelik became the orchestra’s second chief conductor; he held the position until 1979. Unlike Jochum, who had favoured music from the Romantic and Classical periods, Kubelik selected music from more-recent eras as well. Under Kubelik, some of the orchestra’s concerts of contemporary music included guest conductors such as Paul Hindemith and Igor Stravinsky. Sir Colin Davis conducted the orchestra in the1980s, followed by Lorin Maazel in the 1990s. In 2003 the post was assumed by Mariss Jansons.

Remastered By: Wayne Yang, USA-Taiwan

Title: Rafael Kubelik:  A Symphonic Peripeteia for Organ & Orchestra (1983-4)
Description:
The Czech conductor and composer, Rafael Kubelik (1914-1996) is probably better known as a conductor than composer.  However, he wrote a substantial body of music, including three symphonies, several operas as well as other chamber music and songs.  One of his most accomplished pieces is the present work which was premiered on March 14, 1985 with Edgar Krapp, organ and the composer conducting the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.  That broadcast performance is presented here.  The work is an extended movement in five sections played without pause.

-Video Upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com

Title: Rudolf Kochert Schumann Violinkonzert D min Rafael Kubelik:Bavarian Radio S.O. Nov, 1966 Munich
Description:
Rudolf Josef Koeckert (27 June 1913 – 7 September 2005) was a German violinist.[1][2]

Life
Koeckert was born in Velké Březno near Aussig, Bohemia. Until 1938, Koeckert studied in the master class of the Prague Conservatory and was concertmaster of the German Philharmonic Orchestra Prague from 1939 to 1945, which moved to Bamberg after the Second World War and took the name Bamberg Symphony. Koeckert was concertmaster there from 1946 to 1947. He then moved to Munich, where he was concertmaster of the Symphonieorchester des Bayerischen Rundfunks for 30 years from 1949. From 1952, he was also professor for violin playing at the Leopold Mozart Conservatory in Augsburg.

In 1939, Koeckert and former fellow students had founded the "Sudetendeutsche String Quartet", which was later renamed the "Prager Deutsches Streichquartett". This ensemble performed in Bamberg (from 1949 based in Munich) under the name Koeckert Quartet from 1947 and made a name for itself in the following years on numerous concert tours at home and abroad, and also through the world premieres of chamber music works by many contemporary composers. In 1950, Rudolf Koeckert discovered a previously unknown string quartet in C minor by Anton Bruckner (1824-1896) and published it in Vienna in 1956. In 1982, he retired from the Koeckert Quartet.

Title: Sir Clifford Curzon’s last Mozart Piano Concerto? Kubelík, Chicago Symphony 1980
Description:
Sir Clifford Curzon plays Mozart’s Concerto for Piano, No. 23, A major, K. 488 with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra conducted by Rafael Kubelík on November 6th, 1980. 

Dramatic video title? Yes, but considering that Sir Clifford Curzon died less than two years after this performance - it’s possible. This neat recording was off the radio - WFMT Chicago. I believe it was a live broadcast if I am reading the Chicago Symphony archive correctly:
http://tiny.cc/curzon

If you know of a Curzon Mozart performance after November 6th, 1980 please comment below! I was unable to find an archive of his performance history unfortunately. 

I’m sure glad that the Marchant family were such prolific tapers off the radio - because I’m pretty sure this recording does not exist anywhere else other than the CSO's archives and I’m grateful to be able to resurrect it for YouTube. It took me a while to interpret Mr. Marchant’s daughter’s writing on the back of the reel box. Thank goodness the CSO has a searchable online archive and I was able to narrow it down. 

Technical Info:
Scotch 111-A
5” reel, Quarter track 1/4”
3 3/4 IPS
Some tape degradation is evident in this recording, and also there were some issues with the right channel being much louder than the left. I believe this is because whomever set up the recording wanted to have the piano mostly on the left channel and the orchestra mostly on the right. But I think tape degradation is also a factor here. I tried to fix this digitally but there is only so much I can do when it changes throughout the piece. Hopefully it’s not too distracting.

00:00 - Movement 1. Allegro in A major
11:53 - Movement 2. Adagio in F♯ minor
19:37 - Movement 3. Allegro assai in A major and alla breve, rondo form

Title: Tristan und Isolde CG 1958 Kubelik
Description:
Tristan und Isolde - 4 June 1958 Evening 

Covent Garden Opera Company
Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London

Conductor Rafael Kubelik

Isolde  Birgit Nilsson
Brangäne  Irene Dalis
Kurwenal  Otakar Kraus
Tristan          Ramon Vinay
Melot          Edgar Evans
King Mark  James Pease
Shepherd  David Tree
Steersman Rhydderch Davies

BBC Broadcast
Act 3 - two excerpts. 22m Tristan's delerium until arrival of Isolde.
                                       7m Liebestod
                                       1m BBC Closing announcement.

These excerpts are all I can find after nearly 50 years of searching.
It was a complete broadcast and considering the other Kubelik Operas broadcast at Covent Garden from around this time, all of which survive, (Trojans, Othello (twice) Peter Grimes and Boris Godunov) it is surprising that a full copy does not seem to exist.
Nilsson stood in as a last minute replacement for Sylvia Fisher.
